Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Chemical Dynamics of Polyatomic Molecules at Surfaces: New Insights from State-Selected Studies
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Arthur Utz of Tufts University and his graduate and undergraduate student colleagues are studying the reactivity of molecules with vibrational excitation on catalytically-active metal surfaces. Scientists believe that metal-atom vibrations on some surfaces may significantly enhance the reactivity of molecules on the surface. Prof. Utz's research uses molecules with vibrational excitation to probe this effect on a variety of metal surfaces. The goal of research like this is to learn more about the way that gas-surface reactivity can be enhanced with catalytic metal surfaces. Studies like this could lead the way to improved catalysts for industrial processes. Students working in the Utz group receive training in ultrahigh vacuum methods as well as in the use of lasers and sophisticated optical systems. Prof. Utz and his group are also involved in educational outreach to underserved schools in Boston.

Prof. Arthur Utz and his research group conduct detailed surface-molecule scattering experiments to probe the ways in which surface metal vibrations modulate catalytic reactivity on a variety of transition metal surfaces. Lasers are used to excite vibrations in molecules entrained in a molecular beam incident upon a variety of transition metal surfaces. Differences in reactivity are probed by monitoring the production of different products as a function of surface temperature and corrugation. Specific reactant gases to be studied include: water, ammonia, methanol, carbon dioxide, ethane and methane. Metals to be studied include: Ni, Pt, Cu and Ru. Questions to be asked include: (1) What are the factors (e.g. identity of dissociation fragments and/or metal surface, local surface structure, etc.) that result in significant modulation of reactivity, and how general is this effect? (2) Is the modulation of reactivity greater at under-coordinated atoms that may undergo larger amplitude motion at a given level of vibrational excitation? (3) Can surface temperature dependence of state-resolved reactivity measurements be used to ascertain details of reaction mechanisms (e.g. barrier height determination)? The Utz research group includes active involvement by undergraduates (Tufts University as well as Stonehill College) in authentic research. Educational outreach takes place with teachers at Josiah Quincy Upper School in Boston's Chinatown neighborhood, designing hands-on activities that complement curricular standards.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Arthur Utz of Tufts University and his graduate and undergraduate student colleagues are performing experiments that reveal the molecular mechanism for industrially important chemical reactions on catalytically active metal surfaces.  The reactions studied are chosen for their significance in large-scale heterogeneously catalyzed process widely used in the petrochemical and chemical industries. In these reactions, a reactant molecule in the gas phase approaches the catalytically active metal surface. Upon surface impact, the molecule breaks into two parts, with each part forming a bond to sites on the surface. In many cases the reactant molecule must distort from its stable equilibrium geometry in order to dissociate on the metal surface and form the fragments that can then undergo further reaction to form reaction products. Since these molecular distortions occur on the sub-picosecond time scale, they are difficult to image or study directly. The experiments in this study, and associated computational work of our theoretical collaborators address key questions in mechanism and energy flow while providing data critical for advancing widely used computational methods. 

Infrared laser excitation of reagent molecules, such as methane, prepares gas-phase molecules with a precisely defined vibrational energy and motion. The reactants are entrained in a supersonic molecular beam that provides precise control over the direction and kinetic energy of the molecule's surface approach.  The vibrational excitation imparts a well-defined deformation (bond stretch and/or bend) to the gas-phase reagent prior to its impact with the surface, while the molecular beam independently dictates the molecules' kinetic energy. By systematically varying the nature of the vibration excited, the group can learn which of these structural deformations are most important for driving the reaction, and how energy associated with different molecule motions can flow within the molecule and impact its reaction probability. Mechanistic insights such as these are critical for scientist's ability to identify and predict new approaches to catalysis that can meet societal needs for more efficient, selective, and tunable catalysts for chemical production, fuel conversion, and fertilizer production.  

Many important industrially catalyzed processes, including methane steam reforming to produce H2 gas, occur at high temperature, but quantitative measures of methane reactivity at high surface temperature, Tsurf > 550K are lacking. The group has developed and refined an experimental method that provides previously unavailable reaction probabilities at temperatures typical of industrial steam reforming reactors (Tsurf ≥ 1000K). These data show that the vibrational excitation of metal atoms in the catalyst surface have significant impact on reaction probability, and highlight an important consideration in catalyst design and modelling of high temperature catalytic reactions. 

Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations have become the go-to computational method for understanding and guiding the design of new catalysts ranging from supported metals and single atom alloys to structurally engineered nanoparticles. Despite the importance of DFT, the method includes approximations that are known to compromise accuracy and degrade reliability. The main factor limiting efforts to improve the accuracy of this computational workhorse is the availability of reliable and unambiguous experimental results to benchmark theory. The Utz group's measurements have emerged as the gold standard for theoretical chemists working to make these powerful theoretical tools more accurate. The experiment's ability to provide absolute reaction probabilities for molecules in single vibrational and rotational quantum states with precise translational energy makes them ideal benchmarks for testing, validating, and refining density functional theory (DFT) based electronic structure methods. Publications resulting from this work are the first to demonstrate chemical accuracy (energetic accuracy of 1 kcal/mol or less) and are guiding a broad range of computational work aimed at identifying and addressing limitations to the accuracy of DFT-based computational methods. Increasing the accuracy of these methods has broad impact in the screening and design of new catalytic materials. 

The work has broad impact on science, society, and education. The availability of high quality benchmark data for dissociative chemisorption has stimulated new work in computational chemistry aimed at improving the accuracy of calculations of barrier heights and the potential energy surfaces that govern reactivity. Surface temperature dependent measurements have shown for the first time that rather than serving as a static template for catalyzing reaction, the surface, and its thermally excited motions, can play a pivotal role in catalysis, and open up new low-energy pathways for high-barrier chemical reactions. Students working in the Utz group receive excellent training in ultrahigh vacuum methods as well as in the use of lasers and sophisticated optical systems and have gone on to make important contributions in industry and academe. Prof. Utz and his group are also involved in educational outreach to underserved schools in neighboring communities to excite the nation's next generation of scientific investigators and innovators.
